title-group.article-title: A seafarer’s reliability assessment incorporating subjective judgements

contrib-group.aff: School of Engineering, Technology and Maritime Operations, Liverpool John Moores University, UK

author-notes.corresp: Ramin Riahi, School of Engineering, Technology and Maritime Operations, Liverpool John Moores University, James Parsons Building, Byrom Street, Liverpool L3 3AF, UK. Email: r.riahi@ljmu.ac.uk

abstract.p: More than 80% of international cargo moves through seaports, making a contribution to the world economy. As a result, the performance of seafarers plays a major role in the safety of international trade and the maritime environment. This paper presents a novel approach to monitoring the performance of seafarers in terms of their conditional reliability. Unlike a traditional reliability analysis of a seafarer, this approach contains a dynamic model capable of coping with continually changing conditions that affect a seafarer’s performance. The proposed methodology enables and facilitates decision makers to assess the performance of a seafarer before his or her designation to any activities and during his or her seafaring period. To evaluate a seafarer’s reliability, a generic model is constructed and a combination of different techniques such as fuzzy logic, a fuzzy rule base, an analytical hierarchy process, evidential reasoning, a mapping process and expected utility is used. Furthermore, by changing the conditions that affect the reliability of an ideal seafarer and through calculating a value for this reliability, a benchmark is constructed. A seafarer’s reliability depends upon many variables and their dependencies; alteration of a criterion value will ultimately alter a seafarer’s reliability. In order to correct any deviation on time, a seafarer’s reliability has to be measured appropriately and regularly.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The UK Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) stated that human error is a factor in the majority of marine accidents.1 Psaraftis et al.2 analysed over 7553 maritime accident reports and found that human factors were the root cause, after taking into account the vessels’ flag, ownership, type, age, type of cargo and location of accident.

In marine operations, the deck and engineering officers are usually designated by a manning and crewing agent or a fleet personnel department based on their certificate of competencies, specific training certificates, medical fitness certificate and sea services (i.e. experiences) without making an allowance for the fluctuation in the reliability of a seafarer due to continually changing conditions (e.g. sea conditions and rest hours).3 This paper presents a dynamic model capable of coping with changing conditions that affect the performance of a seafarer.

The structure of the paper is as follows. The second section presents a literature review on a seafarer’s reliability. The process of building a generic model of a hierarchical structure for evaluating the seafarer’s reliability is presented in the third section, in which both quantitative information and qualitative information are processed. The methodology is then explained and applied to the assessment of a Second Officer’s reliability in the fourth section. By changing the conditions that affect an ideal seafarer’s reliability and through calculating its value, a benchmark is constructed in the fifth section and employed to convert a seafarer’s reliability value to a grade (or grades) of performance. The evaluation of a Second Officer’s reliability under constantly changing sea conditions follows with a discussion.

sec.title: Literature review on the reliability of a seafarer
sec.p: Measurement of the reliability of human behaviour in a human–machine system has been a source of interest since the early 1960s. Swain,4 Meister,5 Askren6 and Adams7 have conducted research in this area. Given that the input data for calculation of human reliability are normally expressed in both quantitative terms and qualitative terms, decision makers may often carry out their judgements based on both quantitative data and experiential subjective assessments. As a result, a proposed mathematical model for calculation of human reliability should be capable of processing quantitative data and qualitative data. A seafarer’s reliability can be defined as a measure of the possibility of his or her successful performance over a period of time (i.e. during his or her watch-keeping period or seafaring period) and under given environmental conditions. Furthermore, the conditional reliability of a seafarer can be defined as his or her reliability value if a condition is known to occur. A seafarer’s reliability depends upon many variables and their dependencies. The most important elements that affect safety and efficiency in the job performance have been discussed in detail previously;8,9 these are briefly discussed in the following.

sec.title: Ergonomics
sec.p: The focus of ergonomics is the design of the human–system interface. This includes interfaces between personnel and the hardware, software and physical environments associated with the systems. Based on the American Bureau of Shipping (ABS) ergonomic model8 the elements that affect safety and efficiency in job performance are listed in the following.

sec.title: Design and layout considerations
sec.p: Design and layout considers the integration of personnel with the equipment, systems and interfaces. The human–system interface can be evaluated by aggregation of seven criteria (i.e. controls, displays, alarms, integration of controls, displays and alarms, video-display units and workstation, manual valve and labelling) which directly relate to the equipment and system performance in the context of reducing the potential for human error.8

sec.title: Design and habitability considerations
sec.p: The ambient environ-mental aspect of the ABS ergonomics model addresses the habitability and occupational health characteristics related to human whole-body vibration, noise, indoor climate and lighting. Substandard physical working conditions undermine the effective performance of duties, causing stress and fatigue.8,10 Ambient environmental considerations also include appropriate design of the living spaces which assist in recovery from fatigue. The ambient environmental conditions can be evaluated by aggregation of the workplace and the living space environmental conditions.

sec.title: Consideration related to seafarers
sec.p: The important factors that are related to a seafarer’s reliability are listed in the following sections.

sec.title: Technical proficiency
sec.p: The Standards for Training Certification and Watchkeeping (STCW) 1995 prescribes the mandatory requirements for certification of deck and engineer officer and watch ratings including requirements relating to age, medical fitness, seagoing service and standards of competence.11 A seafarer’s technical proficiency can be evaluated by aggregation of a seafarer’s qualifications, experience and specific training (it consists of the compulsory and additional courses for deck and engineering officers under STCW 1995).

sec.title: Human fatigue
sec.p: The International Maritime Organization12 has formulated a definition of fatigue which is conceptualised as a ‘reduction in physical and/or mental capacity as the result of physical, mental, or emotional extension which may impair nearly all physical abilities including: strength, speed, reaction time, coordination, decision making or balance’. Global concern with the extent of seafarer fatigue and its potential environmental cost is widely evident across the shipping industry. Maritime regulators, ship owners, trade unions and protection and indemnity clubs are all alert to the fact that with certain ship types a combination of minimal manning, sequences of rapid turnarounds, adverse weather conditions and high level of traffic may find seafarers working long hours and with insufficient recuperative rest.13 Despite the rest hours, additional issues such as rolling, pitching, vibration, noise, workload and ship schedules are also contributing to human fatigue.14 As a result, a seafarer can be subjected to various levels of fatigue due to aggregation of environmental states, rest hours, design and habitability.

sec.title: Non-technical skills
sec.p: Non-technical skills are an additional set of competencies that are used integrally with the technical proficiencies, such as those to manoeuvre the vessel or to set down the anchor. They encompass both interpersonal and cognitive skills such as situation awareness, teamwork, decision making, communication and language skills.15

sec.title: Fitness and strength
sec.p: The fundamental purpose of the assessment of a seafarer’s fitness is to ensure that the individual is fit for the work for which he or she is to be employed, taking into account the particular risk associated with working at sea.16 A seafarer’s medical fitness certificate is a good indication of a seafarer’s fitness and strength but the influences of external and ambient environmental conditions need also to be taken into account. A seafarer is often required to work in situations where conditions are continuously changing. As a result, in addition to holding a valid medical fitness certificate, a seafarer’s fitness and strength under constantly changing conditions may be evaluated by aggregating a seafarer’s health, stress, nutrition and age with respect to a task.

sec.title: Motivation
sec.p: Herzberg17 identified two separate groups of factors that had a strong bearing on motivation. He called the first group hygiene factors (i.e. working conditions, pay and job security) because they strongly influenced feelings of dissatisfaction among employees. He referred to the second group as motivation factors (i.e. achievement, career progression and learning) because they had a role in positively influencing the performance. Herzberg17 stated that managers can forget about their workforce motivation if they do not get the hygiene factors right first.
Mitroussi18 examined 20 motivation factors in the shipping context; the six most important factors from the employees’ viewpoint are listed as follows:

list-item.p: opportunity to learn a new skill;
higher pay;
friendly working atmosphere;
cash bonuses;
personal growth and development;
chance for promotion.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: The criteria outlined in the literature review as significant in terms of a seafarer’s reliability are used as the basis of the generic model. A combination of different decision-making techniques, such as fuzzy logic, a fuzzy rule base, an analytical hierarchy process (AHP), evidential reasoning (ER), a mapping process and expected utility is used to evaluate the reliability of seafarers. The proposed methodology in a stepwise order is presented in the following sections and the flow diagram for calculating a seafarer’s performance is shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Flow diagram for calculating the performance of a seafarer.

sec.title: Generic model for the reliability of a seafarer (first step)
sec.p: Decision makers should understand and have a clear picture of the whole problem before attempting to solve it. This is especially true when there are many criteria to be considered, which in turn may consist of sub-criteria and even sub-sub-criteria. For this reason, it is useful to display the problem in the form of a hierarchical structure. In a hierarchical order as a first level, the goal of the problem is stated. In the second level, there are several criteria, each of which has its contribution to measuring and helping to achieve the overall goal. Then, some of these criteria may be broken down further. The process continues up to the level where decision makers are able to make practical assessments. Based on the literature review of a seafarer’s reliability a generic model with a hierarchical structure, as shown in Figure 2, is constructed. The main criteria, sub-criteria, sub-sub-criteria and sub-sub-sub-criteria that are contributing to a seafarer’s reliability (i.e. goal) are presented in Figure 2. Generally, when constructing a hierarchical structure, only significant criteria are considered in order to avoid an unnecessarily large model size.

caption.p: Generic model for a seafarer’s reliability.

sec.title: Managing the uncertainties (second step)
sec.p: An important point in dealing with uncertainty was made in 1965 with the publication of a paper by Zadeh19 on fuzzy logic. Fuzzy logic is a superset of conventional Boolean logic with extensions to account for imprecise information. Fuzzy logic permits vague information, knowledge and concepts to be used in an exact mathematical manner. Simply, it can be said that the nature of the possibility theory differs from the probability theory, because in the possibility theory the values are not indicated by numbers, but by words, in natural or artificial languages.

For evaluation of a seafarer’s reliability, a decision maker has to deal with two types of data. The first type is quantitative data (e.g. number of rest hours per night and experience) and the second type is qualitative data (e.g. quality of foods served onboard and a seafarer’s health condition under continually changing conditions). Qualitative data can be presented by linguistic variables (i.e. linguistic terms and their corresponding belief degrees). The number of linguistic terms can be selected by Miller’s method.20 Miller showed a number of remarkable coincidences between the channel capacity of a number of human cognitive and perceptual tasks. In each case, the effective channel capacity is between five and nine equally weighted errorless choices. Normally, too few levels are not adequate to represent the real knowledge of analysts, while too many levels will bring extra difficulties in the following assessment.20 As a result, a fuzzy set N~ (e.g. quality of foods served onboard) can be presented by five linguistic terms according to

For decision makers, exploiting a technique for assigning the belief degrees (i.e. β1, β2, β3, β4 and β5) is challenging. For instance, if the quality of foods served onboard is described as ‘not bad’ by a seafarer, decision makers have to assign the belief degrees based on their understanding of a linguistic term such as ‘not bad’. In this case, the belief degrees cannot be assigned with certainty. For example, they may interpret ‘not bad’ as a combination of Good, Average and Bad with a tendency towards Average (i.e. around Average with variations). To deal with this problem a range of belief degrees for β2, β3 and β4 may be assigned. For instance, ‘not bad’ can be ‘49% Good, 51% Average and 0% Bad’, ‘48% Good, 52% Average and 0% Bad’, ‘0% Good, 100% Average and 0% Bad’ and so on. In this case the most-preferred set N~U={(Very good, 0), (Good, 0.49), (Average, 0.51), (Bad, 0), (Very bad, 0)} is called the upper-limit fuzzy set. The more or less preferred set N~M={(Very good, 0), (Good, 0), (Average, 1), (Bad, 0), (Very bad, 0)} is called the median fuzzy set. The least-preferred set N~L={(Very good, 0), (Good, 0), (Average, 0.51), (Bad, 0.49), (Very bad, 0)} is called the lower-limit fuzzy set. To obtain an upper-limit fuzzy set (in the case of disagreement between decision makers) the weight of each decision maker is calculated and all achieved upper-limit fuzzy sets are aggregated with the help of algorithms such as the ER algorithm (see the section on aggregation operations on fuzzy sets (sixth step)). The same is true for obtaining the median fuzzy sets and the lower-limit fuzzy sets.

sec.title: Quantitative data transformation (third step)
sec.p: A quantitative criterion can be transformed to a qualitative criterion by using membership functions of continuous fuzzy sets. Membership functions are found in different shapes, namely triangular, trapezoidal, S curves, π curves, bell curves and Gaussian curves. In general, the membership is often indicated on the vertical axis, with possible values ranging over the real interval [0 1]. Whether a particular shape is suitable or not can be determined only in the application context. The fuzzy set shape defines the relationship between the domain and the membership value of a set.

To apply the ER algorithm that will be described in the section on aggregation operations on fuzzy sets, it is necessary to have all the data and information within the same universe. Therefore, the information and data need to be transformed before being aggregated. A fuzzy rule base is most suited to transforming a fuzzy input to a fuzzy output.

sec.title: Validation of the model (final step)
sec.p: It is an anachronism in the twenty-first century that seafarers are falsifying their time sheets to prove that their maximum hours of work do not exceed 14 h in any 24 h period and 72 h in any 7 day period.31 In addition, many of these seafarers work every week, without a break, for between 4 months and 9 months before getting leave.31 As a result, owing to the lack of precise data and the novelty of this model, it has not been possible to find any proven benchmark results for its full validation. Given such difficulties, a possible method of fully validating the model can be achieved only by using an incremental process, through conducting more industrial case studies. The developed model can then be refined and applied in real industrial applications.

Based on the above, the model has been partially validated using sensitivity analysis. The objective of sensitivity analysis is to test the sensitivity of the proposed model. Sensitivity analysis refers to analysing how sensitive the conclusions (i.e. model outputs) are to a minor change in the inputs. The change may be variation in the parameters of the model or may be changes in the belief degrees assigned to the linguistic variables used to describe the parameters. If the methodology is sound and its inference reasoning is logical, then the sensitivity analysis must at least pursue the following three axioms.

sec.title: Axiom 1
sec.p: A slight increment or decrement in the degree of belief associated with any linguistic variables of the lowest-level criteria will certainly result in a relative increment or decrement in the degree of belief of the linguistic variable and the preference degrees of the model output.

sec.title: Axiom 2
sec.p: If the degree of belief associated with the highest-preference linguistic term of the lowest-level criterion is decreased by m and n (simultaneously the degree of belief associated with its lowest-preference linguistic term is increased by m and n (1 > n > m)) and the utility values of the model output are evaluated as Um and Un respectively, then Um should be greater than Un.

sec.title: Axiom 3
sec.p: If N and K (K < N) criteria from all the lowest-level criteria are selected and the degree of belief associated with the highest-preference linguistic terms of each of such N and K criteria is decreased by the same amount (i.e. simultaneously the degree of belief associated with the lowest-preference linguistic terms of each of such N and K criteria is increased by the same amount) and the utility values of the model output are evaluated as UK and UN respectively, then UK should be greater than UN.

sec.title: Test case
sec.p: In order to investigate the possibility of an error or errors throughout a Second Officer’s watchkeeping (from 24.00 h to 4.00 h and i.e. 12.00 h to 16.00 h) and during his seafaring period (i.e. 4 months or 6 months), it is essential to assess his or her performance in terms of his or her reliability during frequently changing sea conditions. Based on the following information the reliability value of a 30-year-old male Second Officer with 31.2 months of sea service and sailing onboard a containership is evaluated. In addition, the variation in his reliability during frequently changing sea conditions is calculated. The characteristics of the Second Officer, the containership and the environmental conditions are listed as follows.

list-item.p: He holds an approved officer in charge of navigational watch certificate of competency STCW 1995, A-level qualification certificate (mathematics and physics) with grade C and General Certificate of Secondary Education (GCSE) qualification certificate (mathematics and science) with grade C.
He has a valid medical fitness certificate.
He holds the following approved certificates:
Basic Safety Training (BST) certificate;
advanced fire prevention and fire fighting certificate;
radar simulation training certificate;
Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS) certificate;
first-aid training certificate;
survival craft and rescue boat training certificate;
Automated Radar Plotting Aids (ARPA) training certificate;
International Safety Management (ISM) attendance course certificate.
He has stated that the quality of food is not bad.
He had 8 h rest on the previous night.
Based on his statements, the level of his stress is moderate and he is healthy.
The values of the Beaufort number for the last 2 days are indicated as 4 and 5 respectively.
The vessel is partially loaded and the value of the metacentric height is 3 m.

Based on the available data (during design and construction) and pursuant to the ABS guidance notes for the application of ergonomics to marine systems, the grade of the ship’s design and layout is very good.
The ship’s design and habitability grade for the last 2 days is good.
Based on the Captain’s observations, the Second Officer is punctual, needs supervision occasionally and is enthusiastic.
Based on the Captain’s observations, the grade of communication and language skill of the Second Officer is medium, his teamwork is good, and the grade of his decision making is medium.
To estimate his situation awareness, the Captain has demonstrated a scenario. Accordingly, the grade of situation awareness of the Second Officer is evaluated as good.

A promotion can be granted to a deck or an engineer officer by considering his or her qualifying sea service, confidential reports, oral examination results, qualifications and certificate of competency. Qualifying sea service should be accounted for from the commencement of a ship’s voyage to the termination of such a voyage. For instance, where a ship is laid up in a port for an unreasonably long period, such a period should not be taken into account for the qualifying sea service. In addition, during the reliability assessment, the consistency of sea service has to be accounted for via the ship’s tonnage, type, route, mode of propulsion and power of the main engine. A deck officer is eligible for promotion after completion of the following months of sea service.

list-item.p: The Third Officer is eligible for promotion to the rank of Second Officer after completing 18–24 months of sea service.
The Second Officer is eligible for promotion to the rank of Chief Officer after completing 36–42 months of sea service (i.e. sailing for at least 18 months as a Second Officer).
The Chief Officer is eligible for promotion to the rank of Master after completing 60–66 months of sea service (i.e. sailing for at least 24 months as a Chief Officer).

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis (final step)
sec.p: Three axioms introduced in the section on validation of the model (in the methodology section) are used to test the logicality of the delivery of the analysis result. To carry out the study the degrees of belief associated with the highest-preference linguistic terms of each sub-criterion are decreased by z and, simultaneously, the degrees of belief associated with the lowest-preference linguistic terms of the corresponding sub-criterion are increased by z. Accordingly, the results are obtained. It is noteworthy to mention that, when decreasing the belief degree of the highest-preference linguistic term βα of a criterion by z, simultaneously the belief degree of its lowest-preference linguistic term has to be increased by z. However, if βα is less than z, then the remaining belief degree (i.e. z−βα) can be taken from the belief degree of the next linguistic term. This process continues until z is consumed.

The MAIB conducted a safety study during 1994–2004,31 in which the results conclusively showed that human fatigue (due to acute sleep loss and cumulative sleep debt) and poor manning levels are the major causal factors in collisions and groundings. The consequences of poor manning levels will be work pressure and workload at sea. Based on the survey results of Quick et al.,32 the work pressure and workload are significant sources of stress reported by seafarers. sec.title: The performance of a seafarer (benchmark)
sec.p: From an engineering viewpoint, a comparison can only be made relative to a frame of reference. Therefore, to define the membership functions for a seafarer’s performance, the following scenarios are prepared for an ideal seafarer.

The upper, median and lower reliability values of a 45-year-old male ideal seafarer, who is sailing onboard an ideal vessel in perfect environmental states and with a tendency of all criteria towards the best grades, are evaluated as [0.99 0.99 0.87]. Based on the experts’ opinion for this situation, the grade of his performance should be very good. First, suppose that the grade of the ideal seafarer’s rest hours is reduced from very good to average for a short duration (i.e. 1 or 2 days) due to workload at sea. It is noteworthy to mention that a person who does not obtain sufficient sleep is subjected to moodiness, mood swings, drowsiness, hallucination, a physiological stress response and serious health implications.33,34 As a result, the grade of the ideal seafarer’s non-technical skills and his fitness and strength is reduced from very good to good. Accordingly, his upper, median and lower reliability values are assessed as [0.93 0.88 0.75]. Based on the experts’ opinion for this situation, the grade of his performance should be good. Second, suppose that the sea condition is very rough for a long duration (i.e. weeks). As a result, the grade of the ideal seafarer’s rest hours, non-technical skills and his fitness and strength is reduced from very good to average. Accordingly, his upper, median and lower reliability values are assessed as [0.85 0.79 0.66]. Based on the experts’ opinion for this situation, the grade of his performance should be average. Third, suppose that his stress level is very high for a short duration. As a result, the grade of the ideal seafarer’s rest hours, non-technical skills and his fitness and strength is reduced from very good to low. Accordingly, his upper, medium and lower reliability values are assessed as [0.78 0.72 0.62]. Based on the experts’ opinion for this situation, the grade of his performance should be low. Fourth, suppose that his stress level is very high for a long duration. As a result, the grade of the ideal seafarer’s rest hours, non-technical skills and his fitness and strength is reduced from very good to very low. Accordingly, his upper, median and lower reliability values are assessed as [0.69 0.62 0.55]. Based on the experts’ opinion for this situation, the grade of his performance should be very low. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This paper outlines a novel methodology for evaluating a seafarer’s performance by means of his or her conditional reliability. The methodology for evaluating a seafarer’s reliability and the procedure of how it may be applied to a real scenario has been illustrated in the fourth section. The model is one of the first to acknowledge that a seafarer’s reliability value is not fixed and it may change owing to factors such as the well-being of the seafarer (i.e. the level of fatigue), changes in environmental conditions (i.e. the sea state) as well as the conditions onboard (e.g. the habitability). For example, the outlined model shows that, if the grade of a ship’s design and habitability is very bad and the grade of the sea condition is very rough, then owing to noise and vibration the Second Officer would not be able to sleep appropriately. Therefore, his rest hour’s grade will decrease from a good grade to an average grade. Consequently, his stress levels and the condition of his health will alter. As a result, the median reliability value of the Second Officer is 25.3% lower than that of the same person onboard a vessel with a very good grade of design and habitability. Therefore, during the preparation of a specification for the new building of a vessel and throughout its life cycle, ship owners should consider ergonomics appropriately. Apart from ergonomics, another factor that can significantly influence personal performance is a seafarer’s motivation. Based on the analysis, it can be shown that, if the Second Officer’s motivation grade is very high, then his reliability value is 21% more than that of the same person with very low motivation. However, many in the marine industries, regretfully, hardly consider and pay inappropriate attention to the motivation of seafarers.

Evaluation of a seafarer’s performance can be used to develop a preventative measure against incidents. The grade of a seafarer’s performance is significant in order to identify and take preventive measures against incidents in port as well as at sea and for ensuring the appropriate performance of duties onboard. Therefore, to develop a preventative measure against incidents, a seafarer’s performance should be measured appropriately and regularly. A seafarer’s motivation, fatigue and hours of rest are highly dependent on the ship owner’s strategies. The frequency of incidents can therefore be reduced as a result of the ship owner implementing correct strategies and by improving the seafarer’s performance.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The root causes of human error can be segregated into two categories: preventable and inevitable. Throughout the preparation of a specification for the new building of a vessel and during its design and fabrication stages, preventable factors can be diminished by the appropriate strategies. Furthermore, a seafarer’s motivation, fatigue and hours of rest are highly dependent on the operational strategies of the ship owner. By improving the seafarer’s reliability through constant monitoring of his or her performance and timely correction of any deviation, the safety of international trade and the maritime environment can be enhanced.
